Generation I.Red: Often seen swimming elegantly by lake shores. It is often mistaken for the Japanese monster, Kappa .
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Often seen swimming elegantly by lake shores. It is often mistaken for the Japanese monster, Kappa .
Generation I.Yellow: Its slim and long limbs end in broad flippers. They are used for swimming gracefully in lakes.
Generation I.Stadium: Its webbed hands and feet make it a proficient swimmer. May be seen swimming elegantly at dusk in places like lakes.

Generation II.Gold: When it swims at full speed using its long, webbed limbs, its forehead somehow begins to glow.
Generation II.Silver: It appears by waterways at dusk. It may use telekinetic powers if its forehead glows mysteriously.
Generation II.Crystal: It swims gracefully along on the quiet, slow-moving rivers and lakes of which it is so fond.
Generation II.Stadium 2: When it swims at full speed using its long, webbed limbs, its forehead somehow begins to glow. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) It appears by waterways at dusk. It may use telekinetic powers if its forehead glows mysteriously. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: The webbed flippers on its forelegs and hind legs and the streamlined body of Golduck give it frightening speed. This Pok é mon is definitely much faster than even the most athletic swimmer.
Generation III.Sapphire: Golduck is the fastest swimmer among all Pok é mon . It swims effortlessly, even in a rough, stormy sea. It sometimes rescues people from wrecked ships floundering in high seas.
Generation III.Emerald: A Golduck is an adept swimmer. It sometimes joins competitive swimmers in training. It uses psychic powers when its forehead shimmers with light.
Generation III.FireRed: The forelegs are webbed, helping to make it an adept swimmer. It can be seen swimming elegantly in lakes, etc.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Often seen swimming elegantly by lakeshores. It is often mistaken for the Japanese monster Kappa.

Generation IV.Diamond: A Pokémon that lives in lakes. It swims faster than any human swimming champion.
Generation IV.Pearl: The flippers of its well-developed limbs give it shocking speed. It is the best swimmer among Pokémon.
Generation IV.Platinum: It is seen swimming dynamically and elegantly using its well-developed limbs and flippers.
Generation IV.HeartGold: When it swims at full speed using its long, webbed limbs, its forehead somehow begins to glow.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: It appears by waterways at dusk. It may use telekinetic powers if its forehead glows mysteriously.

Generation V.Black: It is seen swimming dynamically and elegantly using its well-developed limbs and flippers.
Generation V.White: It is seen swimming dynamically and elegantly using its well-developed limbs and flippers.
Generation V.Black 2: When its forehead shines mysteriously, Golduck can use the full extent of its power.
Generation V.White 2: When its forehead shines mysteriously, Golduck can use the full extent of its power.

Generation VI.X: It appears by waterways at dusk. It may use telekinetic powers if its forehead glows mysteriously.
Generation VI.Y: The forelegs are webbed, helping to make it an adept swimmer. It can be seen swimming elegantly in lakes, etc.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: The webbed flippers on its forelegs and hind legs and the streamlined body of Golduck give it frightening speed. This Pokémon is definitely much faster than even the most athletic swimmer.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Golduck is the fastest swimmer among all Pokémon. It swims effortlessly, even in a rough, stormy sea. It sometimes rescues people from wrecked ships floundering in high seas.

Generation VII.Sun: It is said that the red part of its forehead grants supernatural powers to those who possess one, so it was over-hunted in the past.
Generation VII.Moon: It swims along the banks of lakes and catches fish Pokémon. It takes them to the shore and quietly eats them up.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: Even fast-swimming fish Pokémon can be disabled by Golduck. It brings them to a standstill and seizes them.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: A professional swimmer, it can continue swimming for two days straight by waving its long tail skillfully.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Its long, slim limbs end in broad flippers. They are used for swimming gracefully in lakes.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Its long, slim limbs end in broad flippers. They are used for swimming gracefully in lakes.

Generation VIII.Sword: This Pokémon lives in gently flowing rivers. It paddles through the water with its long limbs, putting its graceful swimming skills on display.
Generation VIII.Shield: Old tales tell of Golduck punishing those that defiled its river. The guilty were dragged into the water and taken away.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: This Pokémon lives in lakes. It swims faster than any world-class swimmer.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: The flippers of its well-developed limbs give it shocking speed. It is the best swimmer among Pokémon.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: Its body is strong, and it has webbing on its hands and feet. Golduck can swim easily through rough seas, clawing its way through the high waves.

Generation IX.Scarlet: When it swims at full speed using its long, webbed limbs, its forehead somehow begins to glow.
Generation IX.Violet: It swims gracefully along on the quiet, slow- moving rivers and lakes of which it is so fond.
